title: 113_hr4473
content: The "Small Business Growth in Manufacturing Act of 2014" may provide a credit for on-the-job training under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Business Growth in Manufacturing Act of 2014 offers a job training credit for small business employers, equal to 50% of qualified training expenses. The credit is limited to $5,000 per eligible trainee, with a 3-year limit on expenses per trainee. The Small Business Growth in Manufacturing Act of 2014 provides a job training credit for small business employers, covering 50% of qualified training expenses up to $5,000 per eligible trainee. Small business employer is defined as an employer with an average of 500 or fewer employees in the most recent calendar year before the taxable year. The determination for the job training credit is based on the average number of employees expected to be employed by the employer on business days in the current calendar year. Definitions for qualified training expenses and eligible trainees are provided in the section. The taxpayer can claim a job training credit for employees working at least 30 hours per week during training. Special rules apply to prevent double benefits and to aggregate employers. Taxpayers can elect to not apply the credit. The job training credit for employees working at least 30 hours per week can be claimed by a small business employer. The credit is allowed against the Alternative Minimum Tax and is part of the general business credit. Taxpayers have the option to elect not to apply the credit for any taxable year. Technical Amendment: Section 6501(m) of the tax code is amended to include reference to section 45S(e). Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to expenses paid or incurred after the enactment date, in taxable years ending after such date. The amendment made by subsection (c) applies to credits determined under section 45S of the Internal Revenue Code in taxable years ending after the enactment date, and to carrybacks of such credits. Additionally, the research credit is made permanent with an increase in the alternative simplified research credit. The research credit is made permanent with an increase in the alternative simplified research credit. Section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to remove subsection (h) and increase the alternative simplified credit to 20 percent. Effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2013. The amendment increases the alternative simplified research credit to 20 percent and applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
